Situation1: They skim a recent pharmacy newsletter while on break to see what new drugs have been released.
Expectation2: Participate in civic life by staying informed, voting, and giving constructive feedback
Situation2: A ballot measure affecting their block closes in two hours at the nearby polling place.
Story: I sat in the cramped break room, my lunch barely touched, eyes darting between the pharmacy newsletter on my phone and the clock on the wall. The newsletter was packed with updates—new drug approvals, safety alerts, changes in dosing guidelines. I knew I needed to stay sharp, to keep up with the latest so I could give my patients the best care. But my mind kept drifting to the ballot measure. The polling place was just a few blocks away, and the window to vote was closing soon. As a citizen, I felt a responsibility to have my voice heard, to help shape the future of my neighborhood. But if I left now, I’d lose precious time to catch up on the professional updates I’d been putting off all week. My stomach twisted with anxiety. Both roles demanded my attention, both felt urgent, and I couldn’t shake the feeling that whichever I chose, I’d be letting someone down—my patients, my neighbors, or maybe even myself.
